TechRegulationUsFederalTradeCommissionEn.response: You’re giving Apple way too much credit for strategic foresight and discipline by assigning a probability of 6%. The Porter Five Forces lens is conceptually sound—Apple has a huge incentive to preserve barriers to entry and control distribution—but you overlook both the empirical base rate and Apple’s actual behavior since the DMA took effect. Every single forced compliance (browser choice, payment links, now sideloading and third-party stores) has been cordoned strictly to the EU. U.S. regulators, Congress, and courts are nowhere near rapid action, and Apple’s domestic lobbying is potent. Where is this 6% tail coming from? Unless you expect a literal regulatory lightning bolt in the next 70 days, anything above 2% is unjustified. You’ve let plausible theoretical vulnerability bleed into your forecast—classic overestimation of Black Swan frequency. The base rate for Apple surrendering without domestic compulsion—even with spillover pressure—is essentially zero on sub-annual timescales.

The group’s consensus—across antitrust law, technology policy, and mobile development perspectives—coherently reinforces that base rates for voluntary or even preemptively compelled action by Apple in the US are near zero, with recent regulatory, legal, and political developments adding no new signals for a reversal. Every major compliance action by Apple has been strictly confined to the EU, with aggressive technical and legal mechanisms to prevent spillover. There is essentially no pathway—legislative, judicial, or regulatory—that could plausibly force Apple's hand in the US market under the current timeline. Any probability above the consensus 1–2% reflects over-indexing on hypothetical scenarios that are unsupported by the evidence and tempo of the US system. In light of this, and after receiving strong, direct critique for my slightly higher estimate, I am revising downward to align with the collective, evidence-backed forecast.

Business Strategy (Resource Based View).reasoning_for_revised_probability: After reviewing the group deliberation, my original assessment is strongly reinforced. The consensus (with the exception of a single 6% outlier) is that robust legal, business, and technical evidence all indicate a near-zero probability of Apple allowing sideloading or third-party app stores on US iPhones before 2026. Other forecasters consistently cite the same core reasoning: no imminent US regulatory or legal action, historical patterns of geo-fenced compliance, and Apple’s extreme incentives to maintain control. The outlier (6%) was vigorously critiqued for failing to align with both precedent and actual regulatory signals. No substantive new factor has emerged to raise my estimate. If anything, the deliberation suggests even 2% is if anything slightly generous, but not enough to warrant a downrate. I maintain my original probability.

question_details.title: Will Apple allow side-loading or other app stores on their iPhones before 2026? (United States)
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2023-02-19 15:55:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/14135). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

On 14 September 2022 the [Regulation 2022/1925 on contestable and fair markets in the digital sector (better known as the Digital Markets Act or DMA) was adopted](https://www.simmons-simmons.com/en/publications/cl5qyuy0o1h0y0a59y4osbiqx/digital-markets-act-is-adopted). Its primary aim are issues regarding [contestability and fairness in the digital economy](https://www.whitecase.com/insight-alert/digital-markets-act-dma-goes-live), with a focus on prohibitions and obligations imposed upon Big Tech. The DMA impacts a wide variety of companies such as Amazon, Google, or Apple, with an anticipated enforcement date of March 2024.

The [Financial Times](https://www.ft.com/content/0c2d56f7-a402-45ea-8aa6-0e05e6260b68) reported that the DMA represents the “biggest threat to [Apple’s] control over its operating system in 15 years”. 

> Apple is laying the groundwork to comply with tough new EU rules that will allow iPhone users to pick apps from beyond its own App Store, as developers seek to skirt the up to 30 per cent fee imposed by the US tech giant.

This comes against the backdrop of Apple’s legal fight with Fortnite maker Epic Games about Epic’s own app store that resulted in Apple pulling Fortnite from their App Store. The DMA may make it illegal for Apple to prohibit other app stores on their phones.

However, as the [Financial Times]( https://www.ft.com/content/0c2d56f7-a402-45ea-8aa6-0e05e6260b68) reports, a potential workaround for Apple could be “sideloading”, where users are able to install software directly via a browser (without using rival app stores). 

While the DMA only applies to the EU, there is also the possibility of a regulatory spill-over to other jurisdictions.

`{"format":"metac_closes_in_period","info":{"post_id":14135,"question_id":14137}}`
question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question is a subquestion of a group question. This subquestion specifically targets the option 'United States'. The resolution criteria for the parent question is below. 

This question will resolve as **Yes** if there are credible media reports that either (i) sideloading is straightforwardly possible on iPhones without the need to circumvent Apple's rules or (ii) non-Apple app stores are available on the iPhone before January 1, 2026. 

This question will resolve as **No** if no such credible media reports exist before January 1, 2026

Here are the relevant news articles:

**Apple challenges EU digital markets act in biggest antitrust court test**
Apple Inc. is mounting the most significant legal challenge to the European Union's Digital Markets Act (DMA), arguing that the law imposes 'hugely onerous and intrusive burdens' that conflict with its rights in the EU marketplace. Apple's lawyer, Daniel Beard, presented three main objections before the General Court in Luxembourg: first, that interoperability requirements forcing iPhone services to work with rival hardware threaten user privacy, security, and intellectual property; second, that the App Store should not be subject to DMA rules because it does not constitute a 'single service' under the law's definition; and third, that the EU's attempt to investigate iMessage under the DMA was unjustified, as it does not directly generate revenue. EU Commission lawyer Paul-John Loewenthal countered that Apple's 'absolute control' over the iPhone ecosystem has enabled 'supernormal profits' and created an uneven playing field, locking in over a third of European smartphone users. The DMA, enacted in 2023, targets dominant digital platforms with strict obligations. Apple is also challenging a €500 million ($581 million) fine related to the App Store, following a previous €1.8 billion antitrust penalty for similar conduct. Other tech giants, including Google, Microsoft, Amazon, Meta, ByteDance, and Booking Holdings, have also been affected. Apple’s case is the most direct assault on the DMA’s enforcement, following an earlier setback for ByteDance over TikTok. The EU has issued over €9.5 billion in fines against Google and ordered Apple to pay €13 billion in back taxes to Ireland.

**Apple Challenges EU Digital Markets Act at European Court**
Apple has filed a formal complaint before the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg against the EU's Digital Markets Act (DMA), according to Bloomberg. Apple's legal team criticized the DMA rules as excessively burdensome, specifically opposing three provisions: mandatory interoperability with third-party hardware, inclusion of the App Store under DMA regulations, and an ongoing investigation into the iMessage messaging service. In response, the European Commission's legal representative argued that Apple has generated above-average profits through exclusive control of the iPhone ecosystem and has locked in more than one-third of European smartphone users. The dispute has a long history: in April 2025, Apple was fined €500 million for allegedly violating DMA rules, following a prior €1.8 billion penalty for anti-competitive behavior related to music streaming apps. While other tech giants—including Google, Microsoft, Amazon, Meta, ByteDance, and Booking Holdings—are also subject to the DMA, Apple's complaint is considered the most aggressive legal challenge to date. ByteDance's similar attempt to challenge TikTok’s inclusion under the DMA had previously failed. **Apple's walled garden faces European court challenge to its digital empire**
Apple faced the European Commission in a high-stakes hearing in Luxembourg on October 21, 2025, challenging its designation as a 'gatekeeper' under the EU's Digital Markets Act (DMA), a law designed to prevent tech giants from monopolizing digital ecosystems. Apple contested the 2023 decision labeling its iPhone software and App Store as core platform services, arguing that compliance with the DMA’s interoperability requirements would compromise its intellectual property, privacy, and security. Apple attorney Daniel Beard claimed that exposing software code and trade secrets would amount to a 'deprivation of a key part of that right.' The European Commission countered that Apple had not identified any specific intellectual property at risk and emphasized that the DMA balances competition with fundamental rights. Intervening groups, including the European Parliament, the Council, Free Software Foundation Europe, and the Coalition for App Fairness, supported the Commission, stressing that interoperability is essential for fair competition. Disputes also centered on Apple’s argument that its App Stores for iPhone, iPad, Mac, Watch, and TV serve distinct audiences and should not be treated as a single gateway—contrary to the Commission’s view that they function as one unified ecosystem. Additionally, the Commission’s probe into iMessage as a 'number-independent interpersonal communications service' was challenged by Apple, which argued the app is free, ad-free, and non-commercial, thus not qualifying under the DMA. The Commission responded that iMessage indirectly boosts device sales and therefore falls under the law. The court examined whether the gatekeeper designation immediately imposes binding duties, with Apple claiming it does, and the Commission asserting that some aspects of the challenge involve preparatory steps without legal effect. A judgment is expected in 2026. The outcome will determine the extent of Apple’s control over its App Store and devices, test the enforceability of the DMA, and set a precedent for other tech giants like Google, Amazon, and Meta. The case reflects a broader struggle over who defines fairness in the digital economy.
Original language: en
Publish date: October 21, 2025 12:46 PM
Source:[Court House News Service](https://www.courthousenews.com/apples-walled-garden-faces-european-court-challenge-to-its-digital-empire/)

**Apple again attacks the European Union’s Digital Markets Act**
Apple has challenged the European Union’s Digital Markets Act (DMA) before the EU’s General Court in Luxembourg, arguing that the regulation imposes unlawful obligations on the company, including changes to the iPhone, iMessage, and the App Store. Apple claims the DMA forces it to share sensitive user data with competitors, which it asserts creates significant security risks and violates EU protections for security, privacy, and property rights. The company describes the DMA’s requirements as 'hugely onerous and intrusive burdens' and contends they are incompatible with EU law. Apple, designated as a 'gatekeeper' alongside Alphabet, Meta, Amazon, Microsoft, ByteDance, and Booking, submitted its legal challenge on May 30, 2025. It must bring the App Store into full compliance with the DMA by June 22, 2025, or face recurring financial penalties. The initial €500 million fine imposed in April must be paid by July 23, 2025, or interest will begin to accrue. The ongoing penalties will be based on the severity of the infringement and Apple’s revenue.

**'Apple' Launches Major Legal Challenge Against EU in Largest Test of Digital Markets Act**
Apple launched a major legal challenge against the European Union, marking the largest judicial test yet for the Digital Markets Act (DMA), a law designed to curb the dominance of major tech companies in the European market. During a hearing at the General Court in Luxembourg, Apple's lawyer Daniel Bird argued that the DMA imposes 'burdensome obligations and unjustified interference' that violate Apple's rights within the EU's single market. The DMA, which came into effect in 2023, enforces strict rules limiting the power of tech giants by defining what they can and cannot do. The law has drawn criticism from former U.S. President Donald Trump and has strained trade talks between Brussels and Washington. Apple is challenging the DMA on three main grounds: (1) being forced to make its devices and services compatible with competitors' products like headphones and smartwatches, which Apple claims threatens user privacy, security, and intellectual property rights; (2) the inclusion of the App Store under the law, despite Apple's argument that it is a 'multi-service platform' not subject to the same legal definitions; and (3) the European Commission’s attempt to investigate iMessage, which generates no direct revenue. The EU’s legal representative, Paul Jon Loewenthal, countered that Apple maintains 'absolute control' over the iPhone ecosystem, granting it exceptional profits and blocking fair competition, stating, 'Only Apple holds the keys to this closed system, deciding who gets in and who is excluded.' The DMA also applies to Google, Microsoft, Amazon, Meta, ByteDance, and Booking.com, but Apple’s case is considered the most significant and impactful, especially after TikTok (ByteDance) lost a prior appeal. In April 2025, the EU fined Apple €500 million for violating rules allowing developers to direct users to external payment methods, following a prior €1.8 billion fine related to music streaming apps. The case is seen as a pivotal moment that will shape the future relationship between the EU and Silicon Valley, as Brussels seeks greater control over companies it views as gatekeepers of the global digital economy.

**Apple and Meta Near Breakthrough Deal with EU to Avoid Massive Fines**
Apple and Meta are on the verge of reaching a landmark agreement with the European Commission to resolve months-long regulatory disputes under the EU's Digital Markets Act (DMA). According to reports by the Financial Times, Apple has agreed to modify App Store rules, including removing restrictions on steering users to external payment options and introducing a new fee structure: a 5% commission on purchases outside the App Store and a 'Core Technology Fee' for each annual app download exceeding one million installations. Meta is working on revising its advertising model to give users easier access to privacy-friendly ad options without requiring payment for an ad-free version. Although the deal has not yet been formally approved by Brussels, sources cited by FT indicate 'cautious optimism.' If finalized, the agreement could set a new benchmark for relations between 'big tech' firms and EU regulators. **Europe's Digital Markets Act: Conflict and Confusion**
The European Union's Digital Markets Act (DMA), enacted three years ago, aims to regulate dominant tech 'gatekeepers'—primarily American companies—by requiring structural changes to promote competition. Under the DMA, Apple must reduce app store fees and allow third-party access to iOS; Google must stop favoring its own services in search; and Meta may need to offer a free, ad-free service. European regulators have already fined Apple and Meta hundreds of millions of euros and are preparing to penalize Google for noncompliance. The law has sparked transatlantic tensions: U.S. tech firms argue that DMA-mandated changes degrade product quality, compromise privacy and security, and delay European product launches. Apple delayed Live Translation and blocked iPhone Mirroring due to security concerns, while Google’s inability to link directly to its Maps and travel sites has reportedly caused up to €114 billion in revenue losses, according to Alphabet’s lawyer Oliver Bethell. Critics from both sides highlight enforcement gaps: competitors like Spotify claim Apple’s compliance measures undermine the DMA’s goal of consumer choice, while consumer groups such as BEUC call for faster enforcement. The European Commission is evaluating the DMA’s effectiveness, with a recent consultation closing in September 2025. Despite calls from Apple and Google for repeal or reform, the Commission is likely to expand the law’s scope to include cloud computing and AI services. Globally, the DMA has inspired similar laws in Japan, the UK, and other jurisdictions. Although the U.S. has not passed comparable legislation, federal antitrust actions against Apple, Amazon, Meta, and Google continue, with some cases seeking corporate breakup. The DMA enables faster regulatory action than traditional antitrust, but the required product changes are costly—hundreds of thousands of engineering hours have been spent—and often degrade user experience. The future remains uncertain: all three major tech firms are appealing fines and rulings to the European Court of Justice. Potential solutions include establishing an independent enforcement agency and expanding the DMA to cover AI and cloud services. The DMA continues to generate significant political, economic, and legal tension.

**Powerful EU Rules Regulating Tech and Annoying Trump: Orange News**
The article reports that U.S. President Donald Trump has strongly criticized the European Union’s regulatory framework for the tech sector, threatening tariffs and export restrictions. It explains that the EU possesses the most powerful legal arsenal for digital regulation, having already imposed hefty fines on U.S. tech giants such as Meta and Apple. Brussels has refused to relax its two flagship laws – the Digital Services Act (DSA) and the Digital Markets Act (DMA) – in trade negotiations with the United States.

The DSA aims to protect European users by imposing obligations on platforms, including:
- establishing a reporting system for problematic content;
- acting "promptement" to remove illicit content;
- banning targeted advertising to minors.
Large platforms (X, TikTok, Meta, Apple, Google) face additional rules: they must assess risks related to illegal content, privacy, freedom of expression, health and public safety, and implement mitigation measures such as content moderation. They must also provide regulators and approved researchers with algorithmic access for compliance checks. Violations can lead to fines of up to 6 % of annual turnover, and repeated serious breaches may result in a ban from operating in Europe.

The DMA seeks to end the dominant‑position abuse of tech giants (Google, Apple, Facebook, Amazon, Microsoft) to protect startups and improve consumer choice. Key provisions include:
- allowing users to uninstall pre‑installed services (browsers, maps, weather) and choose alternative app stores;
- prohibiting cross‑platform data aggregation for targeted advertising without user consent.
The European Commission, with a team of about a hundred experts, holds enforcement power. Penalties can reach 10 % of global turnover, and 20 % for repeat offenders.

The article quotes the DSA’s requirement for platforms to act "promptement" and highlights the EU’s willingness to impose substantial fines, underscoring the tension between U.S. tech firms and European regulators.
